sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Non-invasive methods for observing the morphology of living oleaginous yeast are ideal for optimizing the production of various oils, such as food oils, oleochemicals, and biodiesel, from oleaginous yeast. However, existing methods have been developed to target budding yeast without high oil production ability and extract regions of entire cells. This study is the first to target oleaginous yeast, namely, Lipomyces starkeyi, demonstrating a method for extracting regions of L. starkeyi directly influencing oil production through the unique optical properties of L. starkeyi. Specifically, we exploited changes in the brightness along the z-stack depth of multiple z-stack images obtained using confocal microscopy. Because this brightness change was unique to lipid droplets, pixels corresponding to lipid droplets were easily identified, allowing calculations of the parameters of visual features. The obtained parameters of visual features were then used as input for a semantic segmentation algorithm to accurately distinguish lipid droplets from other organelles, including organelles similar to lipid droplets in shape. Experimental results showed that our method successfully estimated the growth status of L. starkeyi, which, to date, is obtainable through invasive biochemical methods only. Moreover, our method non-invasively determined the shape of each yeast cell over the cultivation period to enable single-cell analysis, which has not been achieved with conventional biochemical methods.

p.italic: We propose a method to extract regions of L. starkeyi influencing oil production.
Our method requires only confocal microscopy images and is completely non-invasive.
Our method estimated the growth status of L. starkeyi to enable single-cell analysis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During the cultivation of L. starkeyi, it is necessary to estimate the amount of lipid droplets for quality assessment and growth forecasting. Observations at the single-cell level (Schier 2020) are also beneficial for understanding the oil production process. Because invasive methods (Takaku et al 2021; Angerbauer et al 2008; Yamazaki et al 2019) destroy cells, non-invasive methods are ideal.

Methods targeting budding yeast have been proposed for the non-invasive analysis of yeast cell morphology. Doncic et al (2013) developed a semi-automatic algorithm to segment and track budding yeast, namely, Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Versari et al (2017) improved a segmentation algorithm called snakes (Kass et al 1988) to enable the tracking of budding yeast cells using brightfield microscopy. CalMorph (Kubo et al 2019; Ghanegolmohammadi et al 2017; Ohya et al 2005) approximates the shapes of the mother cell and bud in budding yeast as ellipses to calculate their parameters. However, CalMorph uses fluorescence microscopy images and needs stained cells. YeastSpotter (Lu et al 2019) is a pioneering work based on deep learning. YeastSpotter applies region-based convolutional neural networks (Mask R-CNNs) (He et al 2017) to segment yeast regions. The model was trained by using images from the Broad Bioimage Benchmark Collection (Ljosa et al 2013), which are mostly human nuclei rather than yeast cells. Furthermore, Kruitbosch et al (2021) developed a method to segment budding yeast via Mask R-CNN and track cells across frames of microscopy movies with density-based spatial clustering (Ester et al 1996). Based on our research aim, that is, non-invasive extraction of lipid droplet regions in L. starkeyi, the drawbacks of existing methods can be summarized as follows. CalMorph (Kubo et al 2019; Ghanegolmohammadi et al 2017; Ohya et al 2005) is not totally non-invasive as it requires staining. YeastSpotter (Lu et al 2019) does not exploit visual characteristics to distinguish lipid droplets from whole cells; thus, its performance is limited.

In contrast to the above studies, we developed a method to extract regions of lipid droplets in cells of L. starkeyi. This is because lipid droplets are important organelles that directly influence oil production. In this study, we used confocal microscopy to capture z-stack images because of its generality and ability to produce high definition images. In quantitative phase imaging (QPI), deep learning has been applied to extract regions of lipid droplets in cells of Y. lipolytica (Sheneman et al 2021). However, QPI requires special hardware. In contrast, our study targets L. starkeyi without recourse to special hardware.

The proposed method utilizes the unique optical properties of L. starkeyi, allowing us to calculate the parameters of visual features to identify lipid droplets. The technical novelty lies in introducing the calculated parameters of visual features into a semantic segmentation algorithm. We supplied the segmentation model with the calculated parameters of visual features to enable accurate differentiation of lipid droplets from other organelles.

The proposed method facilitates morphological analyses of L. starkeyi. In particular, our method can estimate the growth status, which, to date, is obtainable through invasive biochemical methods only. Moreover, our method is able to non-invasively determine the shape of each yeast cell over the cultivation time, enabling single-cell analysis. Finally, our method does not require manual measurements and/or invasive processing (e.g., staining) for quantification. Thus, our method is expected to facilitate automatic control of yeast cultivation and growth prediction.

sec.title: Strain and culture conditions
Measurement of lipid production by an invasive method
sec.p: The method for image processing proposed in this study can non-invasively estimate the lipid production status. The invasive biochemical method explained here was used as a reference method to verify the effectiveness of our method described in “Results and discussion.”

sec.title: Data for image processing
sec.p: To prepare ground truths for extracting regions of lipid droplets, we stained L. starkeyi with BODIPY (Takayama 2021). Our microscope can simultaneously shoot brightfield images and fluorescence images without misregistration. We used brightfield images as input for detection and fluorescence images for defining ground truths. The fluorescence images allow us to vividly observe regions of lipid droplets only.

We describe the specific processing steps for defining ground truths below. First, fluorescence images were denoted by F(x, y, z). Bright regions can be considered candidates of ground truths. Thus, we applied Otsu’s binarization method (Otsu 1979) to each of F(x, y, z) to obtain the binary image B(x, y, z). However, this may result in over-detection of background regions when the entire image is dark. In the case of over-detection, the average of each of B(x, y, z) becomes larger than the appropriate candidate of ground truths. Thus, we further applied Otsu’s binarization method (Otsu 1979) to the averages calculated for each of B(x, y, z), removing the over-detected images from B(x, y, z). Binarization was performed for each cultivation time. Then, the remaining images were denoted by T(x, y, z), where elements corresponding to lipid droplets are 1 and the other elements are 0.

We prepared pairs of z-stack brightfield images and corresponding ground truths every 8 h of culture time from 8 h to 168 h. The number of z-stack brightfield image sets was 210, and the number of all images was 3, 360.Fig. 3
Z-stack images with different focal depths contain regions of lipid droplets with a different brightness level. a Z-stack image. b Z-stack image with a focal depth deeper than that of a. c Lipid droplets in the oleaginous yeast. We show lipid droplets in white and other regions in black

sec.title: Optical properties of L. starkeyi
sec.p: Our finding is illustrated in Fig. 3. In regions of lipid droplets, the brightness changed significantly along the z-stack depth. In other regions, such as the background, cell wall, and vacuole, the brightness did not change significantly. This indicates that the refractive index of lipid droplets differs from those of other organelles. Previous studies have reported that the refractive index of lipid droplets differs from that of the cytoplasm in cells (Kim et al 2016; Beuthan et al 1996). To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to quantify the visual characteristics of confocal microscopy z-stack images of L. starkeyi. The next section details how this unique feature of lipid droplets, that is, the large brightness change along the z-stack direction, is implemented in the proposed method.

sec.title: Method for extracting regions of lipid droplets
sec.p: We then combine the deep learning model with the parameters of the visual features in Eqs. 7 and 8. In this study, we adopt Mask R-CNN (He et al 2017), which is used in a previous study (Lu et al 2019), as the deep learning model. The model used in the experiments was “maskrcnn_resnet50_fpn,”2 from the torch vision library. In this study, the experiment was conducted using a randomly initialized model that was not pre-trained. The number of classes was set to two, corresponding to regions of lipid droplets and regions of other structures. In the experiments shown in the next section, we set the number of epochs to 200. Early stopping was conducted if the F1 score for the validation set did not improve over 10 consecutive epochs. The stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method (Robbins and Monro 1951) was used for optimization, with a batch size of four. The learning rate was gradually reduced using CosineAnnealingLR.3 Additionally, invalid annotations, such as isolated regions of approximately one pixel in the ground truth images, were removed prior to training.

sec.title: Evaluation from viewpoint of image processing
sec.p: To quantitatively analyze the unique optical properties of L. starkeyi explained in Section “Optical properties of L. starkeyi,” we created pseudo-tomograms. Figure 5 shows changes in the brightness at the same pixel position as a function of z-stack depth. This figure indicated that regions of lipid droplets were distinguishable from regions of other structures on the basis of the brightness change along the z-stack depth. Specifically, the brightness values in regions of lipid droplets spanned a considerably larger range than those in regions of other organelles.

Furthermore, we verified whether the proposed method could extract regions of lipid droplets. We compared our method with the following methods. MCR:
This is Mask R-CNN (He et al 2017) with the Michelson contrast in Eq. 7.VAR:
This is Mask R-CNN (He et al 2017) with the variance in Eq. 8.YS:
This is YeastSpotter (Lu et al 2019), that is, the standard tool for yeast cell segmentation. The original purpose of the method was to non-invasively extract regions of whole cells rather than lipid droplets. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are no methods specialized to lipid droplet detection in L. starkeyi. In this context, YeastSpotter is most relevant to our research aim. Because YeastSpotter is based on Mask R-CNN, it becomes a suitable reference method for fair comparison if we retrain it for lipid droplet detection. Therefore, we trained YeastSpotter to detect lipid droplets in this comparative experiment. Here, YeastSpotter required a single image as input. Thus, a Laplacian filter (Jain et al 1995) was applied to each z-stack image, and the sum of the absolute values of the obtained luminance was calculated. The image yielding the highest sum was used as the input for this method.

sec.title: Evaluation from viewpoint of cultivation monitoring
sec.p: Here, the numerator was calculated using the proposed method (MCR+VAR), and the denominator was calculated using YeastSpotter (Lu et al 2019). Note that YeastSpotter here is different from YS in “Evaluation from viewpoint of image processing.” Here, YeastSpotter was trained using 32 images per cultivation time (total 672 images) to segment cell regions. In the same manner as YS in “Evaluation from viewpoint of image processing,” Laplacian filter-based image selection was carried out to generate the input for this method. Note that this estimation is completely non-invasive because our method is based on image processing and does not require invasive processing such as freeze-drying and staining.

Figure 8 shows the statistics for the above calculations (a)–(e). These figures indicated that each cell was at a different growth state even if the cultivation environment and time were the same. This supports the necessity of single-cell analysis, which cannot be achieved with conventional invasive biochemical methods. In particular, Fig. 8a and b indicates that each cell and lipid droplet exhibited a different growth trend. Moreover, Fig. 8d and e indicates that cells and lipid droplets became circular as cultivation proceeded. As shown in Fig. 9, our method allows us to observe the morphology of each cell and lipid droplet. A comparison of Fig. 9a–c and Fig. 9d–f revealed that the circularity of many cells and lipid droplets increased slightly, and the shapes of individual cells and droplets were different.

Finally, future perspectives of this study are given. We can adopt or combine metrics other than the Michelson contrast and variance if they can represent the brightness change along the z-stack depth. Although this study adopted the Michelson contrast and variance as the typical metrics, we will test the effectiveness of alternatives in future work. Our feature extraction method based on the optical properties of lipid droplets can be introduced into other architectures of deep learning. Therefore, performance can be improved by adopting newer architectures and enlarging the training dataset through an automatic cultivation control system. Our method can be potentially applied to other oleaginous yeast. To this aim, we need to retrain a deep learning model according to the target yeast. Moreover, because our method utilizes the brightness change that is peculiar to lipid droplets, the suitable shooting method (e.g. confocal microscopy) is necessary. In addition, our method would be effective in the case where refractive indices of the lipid droplet and surrounding organelle are clearly different. Future work includes application of our method to other types of oleaginous yeast, such as R. toruloides (Park et al 2018; Pham et al 2020). Furthermore, the morphology of cells in the culture broth is known to reflect their cultivation conditions. Our non-invasive method allows analysis of both cell morphology and lipid content to facilitate the optimization of microbial lipid production.
